tenses.description: Used for habits, routines, and general truths.
tenses.structure: Subject + base verb (add -s/-es for third-person singular)

exercises.question: She ___ (go) to school every day.
exercises.explanation: In Present Simple, third-person singular subjects (she, he, it) take a verb with -s or -es.

exercises.question: They ___ (live) in New York.
exercises.explanation: In Present Simple, plural subjects use the base form of the verb without -s.

exercises.question: The sun ___ (rise) in the east.
exercises.explanation: In Present Simple, third-person singular subjects (the sun) take a verb with -s or -es. This is also a general truth.

exercises.question: I ___ (not/drink) coffee in the evening.
exercises.explanation: In Present Simple negative, first-person subjects use 'don't' + base verb.

exercises.question: ___ he ___ (speak) English fluently?
exercises.explanation: In Present Simple questions, use 'Does' + subject + base verb for third-person singular subjects.

tenses.description: Used for actions happening now or temporary actions.

exercises.question: They ___ (play) football right now.
exercises.explanation: In Present Continuous, use 'are' + verb-ing for plural subjects like 'they'.

exercises.question: She ___ (study) for her exam this week.
exercises.explanation: In Present Continuous, use 'is' + verb-ing for third-person singular subjects.

exercises.question: I ___ (not/watch) TV at the moment.
exercises.explanation: In Present Continuous negative, first-person subjects use 'am not' + verb-ing.

exercises.question: ___ you ___ (wait) for someone?
exercises.explanation: In Present Continuous questions, use 'Are' + subject + verb-ing.

exercises.question: Look! The baby ___ (cry) again.
exercises.explanation: In Present Continuous, use 'is' + verb-ing for actions happening right now.

tenses.description: Used for past experiences or actions with present relevance.
examples: I have just finished my homework.

exercises.question: I ___ (finish) my homework.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect, use 'have' + past participle for actions completed recently or with present relevance.

exercises.question: She ___ (never/visit) Australia.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect, use 'has' + past participle with third-person singular subjects for life experiences.

exercises.question: They ___ (already/eat) lunch.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect, use 'have' + past participle with plural subjects for recently completed actions.

exercises.question: ___ you ever ___ (be) to Japan?
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect questions, use 'Have' + subject + past participle to ask about experiences.

exercises.question: She ___ just ___ (receive) the package.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect with 'just', use 'has' + past participle for third-person singular subjects to indicate a very recent action.

tenses.description: Used for actions that started in the past and continue to be relevant in the present.
examples: I have been studying for two hours.
She has been working here since 2019.

exercises.question: She ___ (work) here for five years.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect Continuous, use 'has been' + verb-ing for actions that started in the past and continue in the present.

exercises.question: I ___ (learn) English since I was a child.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect Continuous, use 'have been' + verb-ing for ongoing actions that started in the past.

exercises.question: They ___ (wait) for the bus for 30 minutes.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect Continuous, use 'have been' + verb-ing for ongoing actions with a duration.

exercises.question: How long ___ you ___ (live) in this city?
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect Continuous questions with 'how long', use 'have' + subject + 'been' + verb-ing.

exercises.question: It ___ (rain) all day.
exercises.explanation: In Present Perfect Continuous, use 'has been' + verb-ing for actions that started in the past and continue up to now.

tenses.description: Used for completed actions in the past.

exercises.question: She ___ (walk) to school yesterday.
exercises.explanation: In Past Simple, use the past form of the verb for actions completed in the past.

exercises.question: They ___ (not/go) to the party last night.
exercises.explanation: In Past Simple negative, use 'didn't' + base verb for actions not completed in the past.

exercises.question: ___ you ___ (see) that movie last week?
exercises.explanation: In Past Simple questions, use 'Did' + subject + base verb to ask about past actions.

exercises.question: I ___ (buy) a new car last month.
exercises.explanation: In Past Simple, use the past form of the verb (bought) for actions completed at a specific time in the past.

exercises.question: When ___ she ___ (arrive) at the airport?
exercises.explanation: In Past Simple questions with 'when', use 'did' + subject + base verb to ask about the time of a completed action.

tenses.description: Used for actions in progress at a specific time in the past.

exercises.question: They ___ (play) football when it started raining.
exercises.explanation: In Past Continuous, use 'were' + verb-ing for actions in progress in the past.

exercises.question: She ___ (sleep) when the phone rang.
exercises.explanation: In Past Continuous, use 'was' + verb-ing for third-person singular subjects doing an action when interrupted.

exercises.question: What ___ you ___ (do) at 8 PM last night?
exercises.explanation: In Past Continuous questions, use 'were' + subject + verb-ing to ask about actions in progress at a specific past time.

exercises.question: I ___ (not/watch) TV at midnight; I was sleeping.
exercises.explanation: In Past Continuous negative, use 'wasn't' + verb-ing for first-person singular subjects.

exercises.question: While he ___ (cook), she ___ (set) the table.
exercises.explanation: In Past Continuous, use 'was' + verb-ing for two parallel actions happening at the same time in the past.

tenses.description: Used for actions completed before another action in the past.
examples: I had eaten breakfast before I left.

exercises.question: She ___ (finish) her homework before dinner.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect, use 'had' + past participle for actions completed before another past action.

exercises.question: They ___ (already/leave) when I arrived.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect, use 'had' + past participle for actions completed before another past action.

exercises.question: I ___ (never/see) such a beautiful sunset before that day.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect, use 'had' + past participle for experiences before a specific point in the past.

exercises.question: ___ you ___ (visit) Paris before you moved to London?
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect questions, use 'Had' + subject + past participle to ask about actions before another past action.

exercises.question: She ___ (not/hear) the news until she got home.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect negative, use 'hadn't' + past participle for actions that didn't happen before another past action.

tenses.description: Used for actions that were in progress before another action in the past.
examples: I had been studying for two hours before the exam.
She had been working there for years.

exercises.question: She ___ (work) there for years before she quit.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect Continuous, use 'had been' + verb-ing for actions in progress before another past action.

exercises.question: I ___ (wait) for three hours before the train finally arrived.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect Continuous, use 'had been' + verb-ing for actions in progress for a duration before another past action.

exercises.question: They ___ (argue) for hours before they reached an agreement.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect Continuous, use 'had been' + verb-ing for ongoing actions that occurred before another past action.

exercises.question: How long ___ you ___ (study) before you passed the exam?
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect Continuous questions with 'how long', use 'had' + subject + 'been' + verb-ing.

exercises.question: She ___ (not/sleep) well before the interview, so she was tired.
exercises.explanation: In Past Perfect Continuous negative, use 'hadn't been' + verb-ing for ongoing actions that didn't happen before another past action.

tenses.description: Used for actions that will happen in the future.

exercises.question: She ___ (visit) Paris next month.
exercises.explanation: In Future Simple, use 'will' + base verb for actions that will happen in the future.

exercises.question: I ___ (not/be) at home tomorrow.
exercises.explanation: In Future Simple negative, use 'won't' + base verb to indicate something that will not happen.

exercises.question: ___ you ___ (come) to the party on Saturday?
exercises.explanation: In Future Simple questions, use 'Will' + subject + base verb to ask about future plans.

exercises.question: I think it ___ (rain) tomorrow.
exercises.explanation: In Future Simple, use 'will' + base verb for predictions about the future.

exercises.question: She ___ (help) you if you ask her.
exercises.explanation: In Future Simple, use 'will' + base verb for promises or voluntary actions in the future.

tenses.description: Used for actions that will be in progress at a specific time in the future.
examples: I will be eating lunch at noon.

exercises.question: They ___ (play) football at 5 PM tomorrow.
exercises.explanation: In Future Continuous, use 'will be' + verb-ing for actions in progress in the future.

exercises.question: She ___ (study) when you call her tonight.
exercises.explanation: In Future Continuous, use 'will be' + verb-ing for actions that will be in progress at a specific time in the future.

exercises.question: I ___ (not/sleep) at midnight; I'll be at the party.
exercises.explanation: In Future Continuous negative, use 'won't be' + verb-ing to indicate an action that will not be in progress.

exercises.question: ___ you ___ (work) late tomorrow evening?
exercises.explanation: In Future Continuous questions, use 'Will' + subject + 'be' + verb-ing to ask about actions in progress at a future time.

exercises.question: This time next week, I ___ (lie) on the beach in Hawaii.
exercises.explanation: In Future Continuous, use 'will be' + verb-ing for actions that will be happening at a specific point in the future.

tenses.description: Used for actions that will be completed before a specific time in the future.
examples: I will have finished my homework by 6 PM.

exercises.question: She ___ (visit) Paris by the end of next year.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect, use 'will have' + past participle for actions completed before a future time.

exercises.question: By next month, I ___ (finish) this project.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect, use 'will have' + past participle for actions that will be completed before a specific future time.

exercises.question: They ___ (not/arrive) by the time the meeting starts.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect negative, use 'won't have' + past participle for actions that will not be completed before a future time.

exercises.question: ___ you ___ (complete) your studies by next summer?
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect questions, use 'Will' + subject + 'have' + past participle to ask about completion before a future time.

exercises.question: By 2030, scientists ___ (find) a cure for many diseases.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect, use 'will have' + past participle for predictions about actions completed before a future point.

tenses.description: Used for actions that will be in progress up to a specific time in the future.
examples: I will have been studying for two hours by 6 PM.
She will have been working here for five years.

exercises.question: She ___ (work) here for five years by next month.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect Continuous, use 'will have been' + verb-ing for actions in progress up to a future time.

exercises.question: By the time I get home, it ___ (rain) for hours.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect Continuous, use 'will have been' + verb-ing for ongoing actions up to a point in the future.

exercises.question: Next week, we ___ (live) in this house for ten years.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect Continuous, use 'will have been' + verb-ing for continuous actions with duration up to a future point.

exercises.question: How long ___ you ___ (study) English by the end of this year?
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect Continuous questions with 'how long', use 'will' + subject + 'have been' + verb-ing.

exercises.question: By December, they ___ (not/wait) for a response for six months.
exercises.explanation: In Future Perfect Continuous negative, use 'won't have been' + verb-ing for ongoing actions that will not continue up to a future point.
